Why, seeing times are not hidden from the Almighty, do they that know him not see his days?
<FI>Some<Fi> remove the landmarks; they violently take away flocks, and feed <FI>thereof<Fi>.<RF>feed…: or, feed them<Rf>
They drive away the ass of the fatherless, they take the widow's ox for a pledge.
They turn the needy out of the way: the poor of the earth hide themselves together.
Behold, <FI>as<Fi> wild asses in the desert, go they forth to their work; rising betimes for a prey: the wilderness <FI>yieldeth<Fi> food for them <FI>and<Fi> for <FI>their<Fi> children.
They reap <FI>every one<Fi> his corn in the field: and they gather the vintage of the wicked.<RF>corn: Heb. mingled corn, or, dredge<Rf><RF>they gather…: Heb. the wicked gather the vintage<Rf>
They cause the naked to lodge without clothing, that <FI>they have<Fi> no covering in the cold.
They are wet with the showers of the mountains, and embrace the rock for want of a shelter.
They pluck the fatherless from the breast, and take a pledge of the poor.
They cause <FI>him<Fi> to go naked without clothing, and they take away the sheaf <FI>from<Fi> the hungry;
<FI>Which<Fi> make oil within their walls, <FI>and<Fi> tread <FI>their<Fi> winepresses, and suffer thirst.
Men groan from out of the city, and the soul of the wounded crieth out: yet God layeth not folly <FI>to them<Fi>.<CM>
They are of those that rebel against the light; they know not the ways thereof, nor abide in the paths thereof.
The murderer rising with the light killeth the poor and needy, and in the night is as a thief.
The eye also of the adulterer waiteth for the twilight, saying, No eye shall see me: and disguiseth <FI>his<Fi> face.<RF>disguiseth…: Heb. setteth his face in secret<Rf>
In the dark they dig through houses, <FI>which<Fi> they had marked for themselves in the daytime: they know not the light.
For the morning <FI>is<Fi> to them even as the shadow of death: if <FI>one<Fi> know <FI>them, they are in<Fi> the terrors of the shadow of death.<CM>
He <FI>is<Fi> swift as the waters; their portion is cursed in the earth: he beholdeth not the way of the vineyards.
Drought and heat consume the snow waters: <FI>so doth<Fi> the grave <FI>those which<Fi> have sinned.<RF>consume: Heb. violently take<Rf>
The womb shall forget him; the worm shall feed sweetly on him; he shall be no more remembered; and wickedness shall be broken as a tree.
He evil entreateth the barren <FI>that<Fi> beareth not: and doeth not good to the widow.
He draweth also the mighty with his power: he riseth up, and no <FI>man<Fi> is sure of life.<RF>no…: or, he trusteth not his own life<Rf>
<FI>Though<Fi> it be given him <FI>to be<Fi> in safety, whereon he resteth; yet his eyes <FI>are<Fi> upon their ways.

They are exalted for a little while, but are gone and brought low; they are taken out of the way as all <FI>other<Fi>, and cut off as the tops of the ears of corn.<RF>are gone: Heb. are not<Rf><RF>taken…: Heb. closed up<Rf>
And if <FI>it be<Fi> not <FI>so<Fi> now, who will make me a liar, and make my speech nothing worth?<CM>
